overview: How to appeal against a Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority decision if you've been refused compensation for a violent crime
title: Criminal injuries compensation tribunal

table.body:
You can appeal to a tribunal if you disagree with a decision by the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA) on your claim for compensation.

You may want to appeal if you are refused compensation or are unhappy with the amount.

The tribunal can:

- uphold the CICA's decision
- increase or reduce your award
- decide you shouldn't get anything

%You have 90 days to appeal to the tribunal from the date of the CICA's review decision.%

If you miss the deadline, explain why you're late - eg if you're waiting for medical reports.

##Help and advice

You can represent yourself at the tribunal, but you may want to get help and advice before you appeal.

You can contact:

- a [legal adviser](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "legal adviser"){:rel="external"}
- [Victim Support](http://www.victimsupport.org.uk/ "Victim Support"){:rel="external"}
- a [local victim services group](http://victimservices.justice.gov.uk/ "local victim services group"){:rel="external"}
- [Citizens Advice](http://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/ "Citizens Advice"){:rel="external"}

*[CICA]: Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority
table.title: Overview

table.body:
To appeal, fill in the form below, giving reasons why you disagree with the CICA's decision.

$D
[Download 'Appeal form' (PDF, 64KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/forms/tribunals/cic/NoticeOfAppeal.pdf "appeal form (PDF, 64KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

You must also provide:

- the decision letter from the CICA
- documents supporting your case - eg medical records or evidence of loss of earnings

Send the form, decision letter and documents to:

Wellington House  
134-136 Wellington Street  
Glasgow  
G2 2XL
$A

table.title: Appeal to the tribunal

table.body:
The tribunal will send a copy of your appeal form to the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA).

The CICA will aim to respond to your appeal within 6 weeks.

You will then have a month to get back to the tribunal with any extra information or arguments.

##How your appeal will be decided

The tribunal will write to tell you if your appeal will be decided using:

- the paperwork in the case
- a hearing

If your appeal is decided using paperwork, the tribunal judge's decision will be sent to you by post.

You will be given at least 14 days' notice of any hearing.

##Hearings

The hearing will usually be held in the area covered by the police force which investigated the crime.

The hearing will be attended by:

- 2 or 3 tribunal judges or members
- a clerk
- a representative from the CICA
- any witnesses

A police officer who knows about your case may also attend if they can help the tribunal.

Offenders don't usually attend tribunal hearings.

##What happens at a hearing

You will be asked questions about the crime and your injuries.

Other witnesses will only come into the hearing room to give evidence, and will then leave.

You or your representative can ask questions during the hearing, and can make points at the end.

You will usually get the tribunal's decision on the day of the hearing.

##Expenses for going to the hearing

The tribunal will send you information on how to claim expenses for going to the hearing, such as travel costs.

*[CICA]: Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority
table.title: After you send your appeal

table.body:
The tribunal's decision is final.

You may be able to ask for a 'judicial review' of the decision if you think the decision was wrong for a legal reason.

If you're unsure about this, you can get [legal advice.](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "legal advice"){:rel="external"}

Before applying for a judicial review:

- write to the tribunal, saying why you think the decision was wrong
- ask for written reasons for its decision

You must do this within 1 month of the date of the decision.

##Asking for a judicial review

###England and Wales

If you live in England or Wales, you can appeal to a higher tribunal, called the Upper Tribunal (Administrative Appeals Chamber).

To do this, fill in the [judicial review claim form](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=2760 "judicial review claim form"){:rel="external"} and return it to the address on the form.

Find out more about appealing to the [Upper Tribunal.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/tribunals/aa "Upper Tribunal"){:rel="external"}

###Scotland

If you live in Scotland, you can appeal to the Court of Session, using the [application for leave to appeal form.](http://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/session/rules/forms/form40_2.rtf "application for leave to appeal form"){:rel="external"}

Send the form to:

$A
Outer House  
Court of Session  
Parliament House  
Parliament Square  
Edinburgh  
EH1 1RQ $A

$C
**Email:** <supreme.courts@scotcourts.gov.uk>  
**Phone:** 0131 225 2595  
**Fax:** 0131 240 6711  
$C
